intro: Pseudogynoxys westonii, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, orange to red composite flowers. The plant typically grows as an annual herb, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, with hairy stems and alternate leaves. Its flowers bloom in the summer months, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Pseudogynoxys westonii is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is relatively easy to grow in well-drained soil.
